docs.snippet: Hoping to calm rising tensions between rival warlords, officials in Kandahar Province said today that they would appeal to the country's interim government to halt possible Iranian arms shipments into western Afghanistan and to improve security in...
docs.lead_paragraph: Hoping to calm rising tensions between rival warlords, officials in Kandahar Province said today that they would appeal to the country's interim government to halt possible Iranian arms shipments into western Afghanistan and to improve security in the country's northwestern provinces. Reports of Iranian weapons moving into Helmand and Herat Provinces have alarmed the local government here and increased mistrust of Ismail Khan, an ethnic Tajik warlord who is the governor of Herat and has nominal control of five northwestern provinces under an unofficial system that divides the country into five military zones.
docs.abstract: Kandahar Province officials, hoping to calm rising tensions between rival warlords, say they will appeal to Afghanistan's interim government to halt possible Iranian arms shipments into western Afghanistan and to improve securiy in northwest; reports of Iranian arms moving into Helmand and Herat Provinces have alarmed local government in Kandahar and increased mistrust of Ismail Khan, ethnic Tajik warlord and Herat governor, who has nominal control of five northwestern provinces (M)

headline.main: Afghans Struggle to Resolve Quarrels Among Provinces Over Arms From Iran

docs.snippet: A British Army general said today that he had arrived in Kabul to discuss the size and composition of an international peacekeeping force, even as Afghan leaders have voiced doubts about the need for the troops.    Maj. Gen. John McColl arrived at...
docs.lead_paragraph: A British Army general said today that he had arrived in Kabul to discuss the size and composition of an international peacekeeping force, even as Afghan leaders have voiced doubts about the need for the troops. Maj. Gen. John McColl arrived at Bagram air base on Saturday night, met today with Hamid Karzai, the provisional leader, and was expected to see the man chosen to be defense minister, Muhammad Fahim, and the one picked for foreign minister, Abdullah Abdullah, on Monday.
docs.abstract: British Maj Gen John McColl arrives in Kabul to discuss size and composition of international peacekeeping force, even as Afghan leaders voice doubts about need for troops; meets with provisional leader Hamid Karzai; Defense Min-designate Muhammad Fahim insists force should not exceed 1,000 (S)

docs.snippet: American-led ground troops fought their way under withering fire today toward Taliban and Al Qaeda strongholds in these snow-covered mountains, and were reported in some places to have pushed to within a few hundred feet of bunkers and caves where...
docs.lead_paragraph: American-led ground troops fought their way under withering fire today toward Taliban and Al Qaeda strongholds in these snow-covered mountains, and were reported in some places to have pushed to within a few hundred feet of bunkers and caves where enemy fighters appeared to have dug in for a final stand. American officers described the battle as the fiercest ground combat in the five months of war in Afghanistan, and said it had thrown American troops, together with Afghan and European soldiers, against an implacable foe, seemingly ready to fight to the finish. At nightfall, with temperatures at the 8,500-foot battlefield falling well below zero, United States Army Chinook helicopters continued shuttling up into the Shah-i-Kot valley, heart of the battle zone, with fresh troops and supplies.
docs.abstract: American-led ground troops fight their way under withering fire toward Taliban and Al Qaeda strongholds in eastern Afghanistan mountains, reportedly pushing to within few hundred feet of bunkers and caves of enemy fighters apparently ready to fight to death; American officials call battle fiercest of war as stress shifts from intensive bombing to ground assault; United States helicopters continue shuttling fresh troops and supplies up into Shah-i-Kot valley, heart of battle zone; map; photos (M)

headline.main: A Nation Challenged: The Scene; Americans Battling Closer to Qaeda Bunkers

docs.snippet: As the Philippine president, Gloria Macapagal Arroyo, was embraced at the World Economic Forum in New York as a standout leader willing to accept American troops to fight terrorists, influential critics at home persisted  over the weekend in askin...
docs.lead_paragraph: As the Philippine president, Gloria Macapagal Arroyo, was embraced at the World Economic Forum in New York as a standout leader willing to accept American troops to fight terrorists, influential critics at home persisted over the weekend in asking what the Americans would really be doing. At the heart of the concern is this: Will the Americans be fighting? And with the Filipino sensitivity about sovereignty, under whose command will the Americans be?
docs.abstract: Philippine Pres Gloria Macapagal Arroyo's willingness to accept American troops to fight terrorists has raised questions among influential critics at home, over what role Americans will play since Constitution forbids foreign combat troops; Bush administration describes presence of American troops as training exercise in which 650 soldiers, including 150 Special forces, will advise Philippine Army how to fight Abu Sayyaf, Islamic militants holding American missionaries Martin and Gracia Burnham hostage on Basilan Island (M)

headline.main: Role of U.S. Forces Vexes Filipinos, Who Have a Sensitivity About Sovereignty

docs.snippet: The midnight raid against two Taliban leadership compounds north of Kandahar on Thursday uncovered one of the largest ammunition depots to survive the American air campaign undetected by coalition intelligence, military officials said today.    Th...
docs.lead_paragraph: The midnight raid against two Taliban leadership compounds north of Kandahar on Thursday uncovered one of the largest ammunition depots to survive the American air campaign undetected by coalition intelligence, military officials said today. The cache included more than a half million bullets for small arms, 400 60-millimeter mortar rounds, 300 rocket-propelled grenades, some 300 100-millimeter rockets and more than 250 automatic grenade-launcher rounds, said Rear Adm. John D. Stufflebeem, deputy director of operations for the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
docs.abstract: Rear Adm John D Stufflebeem reports raid on two Taliban leadership compounds north of Kandahar by American special operations forces uncovered large ammunition depot unknown to coalition intelligence; reports up to 15 Taliban soldiers were killed and 27 others captured (M)

headline.main: Arms Cache Uncovered In U.S. Raid On 2 Camps

docs.snippet: The United States military is revising a risky plan for American troops to search the caves of Tora Bora for traces of Osama bin Laden and other fighters of Al Qaeda, and is offering incentives to get Afghan forces to take the lead, American offic...
docs.lead_paragraph: The United States military is revising a risky plan for American troops to search the caves of Tora Bora for traces of Osama bin Laden and other fighters of Al Qaeda, and is offering incentives to get Afghan forces to take the lead, American officials said today. Just last Friday, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said he was ordering hundreds more troops to join Afghan militia in the hunt for Mr. bin Laden and other Qaeda leaders, in the hope of uncovering intelligence on terror attacks in the works. Officials said then that the plan was to send in about 500 marines and possibly Army troops, and the units began to prepare for the mission.
docs.abstract: United States revises risky plan for US troops to search Tora Bora, Afghanistan, caves for traces of Osama bin Laden and other Al Qaeda fighters; is offering incentives to get Afghan forces to take lead; will send more troops if Afghans balk; US effort would require building and maintenance of substantial base to house troops in area where anti-American sentiment lingers (M)

headline.main: U.S. PUTTING OFF PLAN TO USE G.I.'S IN AFGHAN CAVES

byline.original: By MICHAEL R. GORDON with ERIC SCHMITT

docs.snippet: At a time when Cuba is exhibiting increasing signs of reaching out to the United States, the Bush administration is filling its Latin America policy ranks with officials known for a hard-line stance toward Fidel Castro's government.    Several inc...
docs.lead_paragraph: At a time when Cuba is exhibiting increasing signs of reaching out to the United States, the Bush administration is filling its Latin America policy ranks with officials known for a hard-line stance toward Fidel Castro's government. Several incoming officials advocate an unyielding hostility toward Cuba and the maintenance, if not strengthening, of a trade embargo that is four decades old.
docs.abstract: Bush administration fills its Latin America policy ranks with officials known for hard-line stance toward Fidel Castro's government, at time when Cuba is exhibiting increasing signs of reaching out to US; Castro government has bought $40 million in food from US, has withheld criticism of use of US Naval Station at Guantanamo Bay to house captives, and has offered to increase cooperation on variety of issues, including drug trafficking and fighting terrorism; nevertheless, Otto J Reich, State Dept's top policy maker for Latin America, and Lino Gutierrez, his deputy, are Cuban-Americans who strongly endorse no-dialogue policy; State Dept spokesman says Cuba must free political prisoners, carry out free elections and guarantee human rights before relations with US can improve (M)

headline.main: Bush Hires Hard-Liners To Handle Cuba Policy
